DOC.HEAD: Romania At A Glance
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: GEOGRAPHY _ Romania covers 91,700 square miles and shares borders with Hungary, Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union and Bulgaria. The Danube River empties into the Black Sea on Romania's eastern coast. The north of the country is dominated by the Carpathian mountains and the center by the Transylvanian alps.

THE PEOPLE _ Romania's population of 23 million includes about 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians _ the largest minority _ and 220,000 ethnic Germans. Romanian is the main language, but Hungarian, Serbian, German and Turkish are also spoken. Eighty percent of the population is Romanian Orthodox and 10 percent are Catholics. There also are 21,000 Jews.

ECONOMY _ Romania, whose industry accounts for around 60 percent of the gross national product, exports machinery, metals, lumber, refined fuels and textiles. Agricultural products include corn, wheat, potatoes and beets. Natural resources include oil, natural gas and coal.

HISTORY _ Romania gained independence in 1877 after some five centuries of Ottoman rule. A monarchy before World War II, the country was reorganized along Fascist lines from 1940 until August 23, 1944, when Romania switched to the Allied side. With the support of Soviet troops, a Communist-dominated government bloc won elections in 1946, and in 1955 Romania joined the Warsaw Pact.

LEADERSHIP _ The present leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, came to power in 1965. Noted for his moderately independent foreign policy in the 1960s and 1970s, he is under increasing fire for his home policy, including suppression of dissent and alleged discrimination against the Hungarian minority. Efforts to repay the foreign debt quickly have led to growing domestic food and energy shortages in recent years. Ceausescu's ringing rejection of reform is leaving him with fewer friends, as Warsaw Pact allies move toward democracy and Western countries step up criticism of Romania's human rights records.
